sn35.133:1.2: It is unusual, if not unique, to see a female brahmin with a student. Below, she is referred to as the “tutor’s wife” (ācariyabhariyā); compare Chāndogya Upaniṣad 4.10, where a tutor’s wife (ācāryajāyā) discusses the education of the pupil with her husband. Verahaccāni is not an attested clan name, and Sanskrit vairahatya means “manslaughter”. Given that her husband is rather mysteriously absent, perhaps verahaccāni is a term for brahmin ladies whose husbands were murdered. Compare nirvīrā, a woman whose husband and children are dead. If so, it would seem that she did not merely survive her husband’s passing, but stepped into his role as teacher.
sn35.133:2.7: She adopts these as signifiers of status. Perhaps as a woman she felt the need to assert her status. Nonetheless, the rules of training forbid monastics from teaching someone wearing slippers (Bu Sk 61), sitting on a high seat (Bu Sk 69), or with head covered (Bu Sk 67).
